eccak","type":"bytes32"},{"indexed":false,"internalType":"address","name":"currentRetrieverAddress","type":"address"},{"indexed":false,"internalType":"uint256","name":"totalAmount","type":"uint256"},{"indexed":false,"internalType":"uint256","name":"trustAnchorDataRetrievalShare","type":"uint256"}],"name":"EVT_updatedEscrow","type":"event"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32","name":"_attestationKeccak","type":"bytes32"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_contestationOracleAddress","type":"address"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"_contestationTimePeriod","type":"uint256"}],"name":"applyEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint8","name":"result","type":"uint8"}],"stateMutability":"payable","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32","name":"_attestationKeccak","type":"bytes32"}],"name":"cancelEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint8","name":"result","type":"uint8"}],"stateMutability":"nonpayable","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32","name":"_attestationKeccak","type":"bytes32"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_dataRetrievalEntityAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"contestEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint8","name":"result","type":"uint8"}],"stateMutability":"nonpayable","type":"function"},{"inputs":[],"name":"getBaseEscrowExpiryTime","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint256","name":"timeAmount","type":"uint256"}],"stateMutability":"view","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32","name":"_attestationKeccak","type":"bytes32"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_dataRetrievalEntityAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"getEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"address","name":"sentFrom","type":"address"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"totalAmount","type":"uint256"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"userAmount","type":"uint256"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"trustAnchorAmount","type":"uint256"},{"internalType":"address","name":"contestationOracleAddress","type":"address"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"contestationTimePeriod","type":"uint256"},{"internalType":"uint256","name":"setTimestamp","type":"uint256"},{"internalType":"bool","name":"wasCompleted","type":"bool"},{"internalType":"bool","name":"wasCancelled","type":"bool"}],"stateMutability":"view","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"address","name":"_dataRetrievalEntityAddress","type":"address"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_escrowRecipientAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"getEscrowBalanceFromRetriever","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint256","name":"balance","type":"uint256"}],"stateMutability":"view","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"address","name":"_escrowRecipientAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"getEscrowBalanceSum","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint256","name":"balance","type":"uint256"}],"stateMutability":"view","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32","name":"_attestationKeccak","type":"bytes32"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_dataRetrievalEntityAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"getOracleCanContestEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint8","name":"result","type":"uint8"}],"stateMutability":"view","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"address","name":"_trustAnchorManagerAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"setTrustAnchorManagerAddress","outputs":[{"internalType":"bool","name":"result","type":"bool"}],"stateMutability":"nonpayable","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"address","name":"_trustAnchorStorageAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"setTrustAnchorStorageAddress","outputs":[{"internalType":"bool","name":"result","type":"bool"}],"stateMutability":"nonpayable","type":"function"},{"inputs":[{"internalType":"bytes32[]","name":"_attestationKeccaks","type":"bytes32[]"},{"internalType":"address[]","name":"_retrieverAddresses","type":"address[]"},{"internalType":"address","name":"_outputAddress","type":"address"}],"name":"settleEscrow","outputs":[{"internalType":"uint8","name":"result","type":"uint8"}],"stateMutability":"nonpayable","type":"function"}],"devdoc":{"details":"| A reference contract related to the Trust Anchor Storage's availability address component within the attestations, which is an ethereum-type address corresponding to the smart contract that manages the various economic & regulatory conditions of data transfer from a Trust Anchor to a data retriever. | Within the Trust Anchor Storage's attestation framework, the availability address is generally encrypted via symmetric AES to prevent abstracted PII from being leaked on the blockchain directly. Once revealed however, this contract and all of its storage variables are trivially linked to the attestation that sets this. | | those applying escrow need to be trust anchors | workflow looks like: | | 1) attestation is set | | 2a) managed (user gives pii-holding trust anchor permission to deal with data transfer, select targets, etc.) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta) | | 2b) unmanaged (user gives permission/consent to pii-holding trust anchor to transfer data to another trust anchor manually) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta) | | 3) destination trust anchor puts escrow funds (SHFT tokens) into this smart contract via the \"applyEscrow\" function. this specific smart contract *only* uses SHFT tokens to transfer, this can be extended by either re-linking an upgraded version of this smart contract on the trust anchor manager or extending a SHFT<->Bancor (or equivalent) token bridge. | | 4a) source trust anchor, watching this contract's events, sees that this escrow event has occurred. that means it can send its data depending on: | | 4a i) the \"contestation oracle\", an address that can sign to contest (cancel) an escrow even if the documents have been sent. This \"contestation oracle\" can be equal to address(0) (a null address, and thus no contestation oracle), or the data retrieval entity itself. | | 4a ii) the \"contestation time period\", the amount of time after the sender has triggered a \"sent the documents\" message that the predetermined oracle has to respond and perform the contestation step if they determine the quality/veracity of the documents sent are questionable. | | 4b i) source trust anchor does (an offchain) transfer of user's consented pii data, with the consented data structure available via encrypted bytes in step 2. | | 4b ii) source trust anchor triggers the \"setDataSenderDidSendDocuments\" function in the Trust Anchor Storage. This indicates the transfer of source documents, and gives the oracle (4a i) the predetermined time (4a ii) to respond to the quality of the sent documents. | | 5) destination trust anchor, having received user's pii data, confirms all of the documents transferred match the consented data structure (at this point both ta's have signed/sent at least one message to the trust anchor manager smart contract, so their public keys are available bilaterally for encrypted communications). | | 6) destination trust anchor triggers the \"dataRetrievalEntityValidateAttestation\" function in the trust anchor storage smart contract, completing the chain-of-custody relationship. | | 7a) the source trust anchor then triggers the \"settleEscrow\" function, which confirms that step 6 was performed, and releases the escrow to the source trust anchor. | | 7b) the end-user may trigger the \"settleEscrow\" function at any point after step 6. | | 8) after 30 days, the data retrieval target may cancel their escrow if the sender has not triggered the \"sent the documents\" message.","events":{"EVT_appliedEscrow(bytes32,address,uint256,uint256)":{"details":"event for application of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes)."},"EVT_cancelEscrow(bytes32,address,uint256)":{"details":"event for successful cancellation of an escrow."},"EVT_contestEscrow(bytes32,address,address)":{"details":"event for successful contestation of an escrow."},"EVT_settledRecipient(bytes32,address,address,uint256,bool)":{"details":"event for settlement for a recipient."},"EVT_updatedEscrow(bytes32,address,uint256,uint256)":{"details":"event for updating of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes)."}},"kind":"dev","methods":{"constructor":{"details":"Initializes this contract with the owner set to the calling public address."},"setTrustAnchorManagerAddress(address)":{"details":"Links Trust Anchor Manager to this contract's function flow.","params":{"_trustAnchorManagerAddress":"The smart contract address for the Trust Anchor Manager that should be linked."},"returns":{"result":"   | false: [ will never return false due to require() ]    | true: trust anchor manager address set correctly"}},"setTrustAnchorStorageAddress(address)":{"details":"Links Trust Anchor Storage to this contract's function flow.","params":{"_trustAnchorStorageAddress":"The smart contract address for the Trust Anchor Storage that should be linked."},"returns":{"result":"   | false: [ will never return false due to require() ]    | true: trust anchor storage address set correctly"}}},"stateVariables":{"attestationEscrow":{"details":"mapping of attestation keccak to the retrieval entity to the Escrow itself. escrow = attestationEscrow[_attestationKeccak][dataRetrievalEntityAddress]"},"escrowApplied":{"details":"mapping of the escrow applied from the data retrieval entity to the destination. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowApplied[dataRetrievalEntityAddress][destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]"},"escrowAppliedSum":{"details":"mapping of the escrow applied to the target. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowAppliedSum[destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]"},"owner":{"details":"The owner of this contract."},"totalEscrowApplied":{"details":"total escrow applied (waiting for settlement based on state machine parameter)."},"trustAnchorManagerAddress":{"details":"The Trust Anchor Manager address that this contract is bound to."},"trustAnchorStorageAddress":{"details":"The Trust Anchor Storage address that this contract is bound to."}},"version":1},"userdoc":{"kind":"user","methods":{"settleEscrow(bytes32[],address[],address)":{"notice":"notice: Escrow-receiving party doesn't need to be an active trust anchor, they simply need to have been a trust anchor in the past. (ie. even if they've been removed from the system, their past actions of data transmission are valid, preventing malicious extortion vectors from the upper-level trust anchor manager administrators)"}},"version":1}},"settings":{"compilationTarget":{"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/TrustAnchorStorage_Availability.sol":"TrustAnchorStorage_Availability"},"evmVersion":"istanbul","libraries":{},"metadata":{"bytecodeHash":"ipfs"},"optimizer":{"enabled":true,"runs":200},"remappings":[]},"sources":{"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/Interfaces/ITrustAnchorAttestation.sol":{"keccak256":"0x6da2322f7f6bc0f39638d167c6f7a7507abe19274d264ae85a2e9db547f846a0","license":"UNLICENSED","urls":["bzz-raw://e9a2558b927a03637c55c1333168f817309d7b4b30557a90d35688747fa4d191","dweb:/ipfs/QmamYkdkur3LUGGPveJxNFdG6DZ3CSyfg2nyyxzaWZScGf"]},"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/Interfaces/ITrustAnchorManager.sol":{"keccak256":"0x7ad86dbdeac7202c507e80fc1d9697fb6f2f7232f57a943f955a3a7708dd66f6","license":"UNLICENSED","urls":["bzz-raw://0d85612488eb53a0132f9adc867cbaf9ad371fa1c7cbd60715f2c24dd0a0f14a","dweb:/ipfs/QmYycb8MxMo3379WMw8zWmmFkCiJiu6KMEam7iFYy7nCwo"]},"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/Interfaces/ITrustAnchorStorage.sol":{"keccak256":"0xc8f613fb5548d4937fda1aa78687f18c75c42eb8f478eb9d9fe759dcda9dc1d6","license":"UNLICENSED","urls":["bzz-raw://3a70020a1419b23fc30bdefcb5938a11221c4966b9c715c4f0efb98ffb941777","dweb:/ipfs/QmWV1Rhj2cJNtnFywAviBr7YGRYY5pEiyNbCQ1G5wfXL5T"]},"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/Libraries/ABDKMath64x64.sol":{"keccak256":"0x18d95d0df876276b067a1a37906eb020ca17b3d667e0d1eeaf556786bf1d41d0","license":"BSD-4-Clause","urls":["bzz-raw://16e0d6cadfe0171f2341f1cbfa36197bee4918cfcdf45d0354182a31dc7a1c65","dweb:/ipfs/QmXJMDTVZ7Bnd6pVvRXR38a5v8LoeG7pAtTcFEa5iDMbHa"]},"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/Libraries/SafeMath.sol":{"keccak256":"0x8243ff510c982957d25d2aa417c8f58a76e5508074e1eb4a9cd55674fc9f29f8","license":"UNLICENSED","urls":["bzz-raw://d7542e06c5f6378a3b320e1831009ca1f1e9603a8aba7ba26000811b290f1e6a","dweb:/ipfs/Qmb8hmCov3Run2F6edSvUgv8fyzVdZRY5Jtqu9wdCerA7P"]},"/opt/shyft-ta-node/contracts/TrustAnchorStorage_Availability.sol":{"keccak256":"0x7782c43fbfb37437770e2c198a8cd5ce2a8b9cda039cf821a13ed6353fa07d2a","license":"UNLICENSED","urls":["bzz-raw://4051364a92832306d80b766e9808619895249024055eeddfd4c0db1dfea2b077","dweb:/ipfs/QmUcH1VD5hEsfSb2VPpsNj18MxnuwZF2GoTnZbXD8Ydtr9"]}},"version":1}

documentation.text:
@dev
 | A reference contract related to the Trust Anchor Storage's availability address component within the attestations, which is an ethereum-type address corresponding to the smart contract that manages the various economic & regulatory conditions of data transfer from a Trust Anchor to a data retriever.
 | Within the Trust Anchor Storage's attestation framework, the availability address is generally encrypted via symmetric AES to prevent abstracted PII from being leaked on the blockchain directly. Once revealed however, this contract and all of its storage variables are trivially linked to the attestation that sets this.
 |
 | those applying escrow need to be trust anchors
 | workflow looks like:
 |
 | 1) attestation is set
 |
 | 2a) managed (user gives pii-holding trust anchor permission to deal with data transfer, select targets, etc.) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta)
 |
 | 2b) unmanaged (user gives permission/consent to pii-holding trust anchor to transfer data to another trust anchor manually) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta)
 |
 | 3) destination trust anchor puts escrow funds (SHFT tokens) into this smart contract via the "applyEscrow" function. this specific smart contract *only* uses SHFT tokens to transfer, this can be extended by either re-linking an upgraded version of this smart contract on the trust anchor manager or extending a SHFT<->Bancor (or equivalent) token bridge.
 |
 | 4a) source trust anchor, watching this contract's events, sees that this escrow event has occurred. that means it can send its data depending on:
 |
 | 4a i) the "contestation oracle", an address that can sign to contest (cancel) an escrow even if the documents have been sent. This "contestation oracle" can be equal to address(0) (a null address, and thus no contestation oracle), or the data retrieval entity itself.
 |
 | 4a ii) the "contestation time period", the amount of time after the sender has triggered a "sent the documents" message that the predetermined oracle has to respond and perform the contestation step if they determine the quality/veracity of the documents sent are questionable.
 |
 | 4b i) source trust anchor does (an offchain) transfer of user's consented pii data, with the consented data structure available via encrypted bytes in step 2.
 |
 | 4b ii) source trust anchor triggers the "setDataSenderDidSendDocuments" function in the Trust Anchor Storage. This indicates the transfer of source documents, and gives the oracle (4a i) the predetermined time (4a ii) to respond to the quality of the sent documents.
 |
 | 5) destination trust anchor, having received user's pii data, confirms all of the documents transferred match the consented data structure (at this point both ta's have signed/sent at least one message to the trust anchor manager smart contract, so their public keys are available bilaterally for encrypted communications).
 |
 | 6) destination trust anchor triggers the "dataRetrievalEntityValidateAttestation" function in the trust anchor storage smart contract, completing the chain-of-custody relationship.
 |
 | 7a) the source trust anchor then triggers the "settleEscrow" function, which confirms that step 6 was performed, and releases the escrow to the source trust anchor.
 |
 | 7b) the end-user may trigger the "settleEscrow" function at any point after step 6.
 |
 | 8) after 30 days, the data retrieval target may cancel their escrow if the sender has not triggered the "sent the documents" message.
@dev event for application of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes).
@dev event for updating of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes).
@dev event for successful contestation of an escrow.
@dev event for successful cancellation of an escrow.
@dev event for settlement for a recipient.
@dev mapping of attestation keccak to the retrieval entity to the Escrow itself. escrow = attestationEscrow[_attestationKeccak][dataRetrievalEntityAddress]
@dev total escrow applied (waiting for settlement based on state machine parameter).
@dev mapping of the escrow applied from the data retrieval entity to the destination. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowApplied[dataRetrievalEntityAddress][destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]
@dev mapping of the escrow applied to the target. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowAppliedSum[destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]
@dev The Trust Anchor Manager address that this contract is bound to.
@dev The Trust Anchor Storage address that this contract is bound to.
@dev Initializes this contract with the owner set to the calling public address.

typeDescriptions.typeString: mapping(bytes32 => mapping(address => struct TrustAnchorStorage_Availability.escrow storage ref))

documentation.text: notice: Escrow-receiving party doesn't need to be an active trust anchor, they simply need to have been a trust anchor in the past. (ie. even if they've been removed from the system, their past actions of data transmission are valid, preventing malicious extortion vectors from the upper-level trust anchor manager administrators)

typeDescriptions.typeString: mapping(bytes32 => mapping(address => struct TrustAnchorStorage_Availability.escrow storage ref))

attributes.text:
@dev
 | A reference contract related to the Trust Anchor Storage's availability address component within the attestations, which is an ethereum-type address corresponding to the smart contract that manages the various economic & regulatory conditions of data transfer from a Trust Anchor to a data retriever.
 | Within the Trust Anchor Storage's attestation framework, the availability address is generally encrypted via symmetric AES to prevent abstracted PII from being leaked on the blockchain directly. Once revealed however, this contract and all of its storage variables are trivially linked to the attestation that sets this.
 |
 | those applying escrow need to be trust anchors
 | workflow looks like:
 |
 | 1) attestation is set
 |
 | 2a) managed (user gives pii-holding trust anchor permission to deal with data transfer, select targets, etc.) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta)
 |
 | 2b) unmanaged (user gives permission/consent to pii-holding trust anchor to transfer data to another trust anchor manually) sets a data retrieval target (must be valid ta)
 |
 | 3) destination trust anchor puts escrow funds (SHFT tokens) into this smart contract via the "applyEscrow" function. this specific smart contract *only* uses SHFT tokens to transfer, this can be extended by either re-linking an upgraded version of this smart contract on the trust anchor manager or extending a SHFT<->Bancor (or equivalent) token bridge.
 |
 | 4a) source trust anchor, watching this contract's events, sees that this escrow event has occurred. that means it can send its data depending on:
 |
 | 4a i) the "contestation oracle", an address that can sign to contest (cancel) an escrow even if the documents have been sent. This "contestation oracle" can be equal to address(0) (a null address, and thus no contestation oracle), or the data retrieval entity itself.
 |
 | 4a ii) the "contestation time period", the amount of time after the sender has triggered a "sent the documents" message that the predetermined oracle has to respond and perform the contestation step if they determine the quality/veracity of the documents sent are questionable.
 |
 | 4b i) source trust anchor does (an offchain) transfer of user's consented pii data, with the consented data structure available via encrypted bytes in step 2.
 |
 | 4b ii) source trust anchor triggers the "setDataSenderDidSendDocuments" function in the Trust Anchor Storage. This indicates the transfer of source documents, and gives the oracle (4a i) the predetermined time (4a ii) to respond to the quality of the sent documents.
 |
 | 5) destination trust anchor, having received user's pii data, confirms all of the documents transferred match the consented data structure (at this point both ta's have signed/sent at least one message to the trust anchor manager smart contract, so their public keys are available bilaterally for encrypted communications).
 |
 | 6) destination trust anchor triggers the "dataRetrievalEntityValidateAttestation" function in the trust anchor storage smart contract, completing the chain-of-custody relationship.
 |
 | 7a) the source trust anchor then triggers the "settleEscrow" function, which confirms that step 6 was performed, and releases the escrow to the source trust anchor.
 |
 | 7b) the end-user may trigger the "settleEscrow" function at any point after step 6.
 |
 | 8) after 30 days, the data retrieval target may cancel their escrow if the sender has not triggered the "sent the documents" message.
@dev event for application of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes).
@dev event for updating of escrow by data retrieval target, including all pertinent details (things like block timestamp can be calculated offline for logging purposes).
@dev event for successful contestation of an escrow.
@dev event for successful cancellation of an escrow.
@dev event for settlement for a recipient.
@dev mapping of attestation keccak to the retrieval entity to the Escrow itself. escrow = attestationEscrow[_attestationKeccak][dataRetrievalEntityAddress]
@dev total escrow applied (waiting for settlement based on state machine parameter).
@dev mapping of the escrow applied from the data retrieval entity to the destination. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowApplied[dataRetrievalEntityAddress][destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]
@dev mapping of the escrow applied to the target. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowAppliedSum[destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]
@dev The Trust Anchor Manager address that this contract is bound to.
@dev The Trust Anchor Storage address that this contract is bound to.
@dev Initializes this contract with the owner set to the calling public address.

EVT_cancelEscrow(bytes32,address,uint256.details: event for successful cancellation of an escrow.

returns.result: | false: [ will never return false due to require() ]    | true: trust anchor manager address set correctly

returns.result: | false: [ will never return false due to require() ]    | true: trust anchor storage address set correctly

attestationEscrow.details: mapping of attestation keccak to the retrieval entity to the Escrow itself. escrow = attestationEscrow[_attestationKeccak][dataRetrievalEntityAddress]

escrowApplied.details: mapping of the escrow applied from the data retrieval entity to the destination. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowApplied[dataRetrievalEntityAddress][destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]

escrowAppliedSum.details: mapping of the escrow applied to the target. escrow_ready_to_settle = escrowAppliedSum[destinationAddressThatCanRedeem]

totalEscrowApplied.details: total escrow applied (waiting for settlement based on state machine parameter).

trustAnchorManagerAddress.details: The Trust Anchor Manager address that this contract is bound to.

trustAnchorStorageAddress.details: The Trust Anchor Storage address that this contract is bound to.

settleEscrow(bytes32[],address[],address.notice: notice: Escrow-receiving party doesn't need to be an active trust anchor, they simply need to have been a trust anchor in the past. (ie. even if they've been removed from the system, their past actions of data transmission are valid, preventing malicious extortion vectors from the upper-level trust anchor manager administrators)
